Wood|William W. W. Wood]] (father-in-law) | laterwork = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = }}
'''Conway Hillyer Arnold''', USN, (14 November 1848 - 16 July 1917) was a [[Rear admiral (United States)|rear admiral]] of the [[United States Navy]], in command of the Third Squadron of the [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Atlantic Fleet]] in 1910.
==Early life == He was born on 14 November 1848 in New York to Commander Henry Nathan Tewkesbury and Cornelia Van Vleck Sleight.<ref name="auto">Marquis Who's Who, Inc. ''Who Was Who in American History, the Military''. Chicago: Marquis Who's Who, 1975. P. 16 ISBN 0837932017 {{OCLC|657162692}}</ref>
==Career == In 1867, he graduated from the [[United States Naval Academy]],<ref name="auto"/> and in 1868 was commissioned as an [[ensign]] in the [[United States Navy]].
In 1870, Arnold was commissioned as a master. The following year, he was promoted to the rank of [[Lieutenant]]. After many years as a Lieutenant, Arnold was commissioned to the rank of [[Lieutenant Commander]] in 1892.<ref name="auto"/>
At the onset of the [[Spanish American War]], he was promoted to the rank of [[Commander (United States)|Commander]]. In 1902, he obtained the rank of [[Captain (United States)|captain]]. Then, by 1908, he was promoted to the position of [[Rear admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] and placed in charge of the Third Squadron of the [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Atlantic Fleet]]
==Personal life and family == On 17 November 1870, he married Fannie Wood of Raleigh, North Carolina, daughter of [[William W. Wood|William W. W. Wood]], Engineer in Chief of the United States Navy.<ref name="auto"/>
His son Conway Hillyer Arnold Jr., who also served with distinction in the military, died at a young age on 6 April 1908<ref name="auto1">{{cite news|title=Obituary of Conway Hillyer Arnold|url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F70916FB385E11738DDDAE0994DF405B878DF1D3|work=New York Times, July 17, 1917 |date=July 17, 1917}}</ref> in Denver, Colorado, possibly of tuberculosis.
==Death and legacy == He died on 16 July 1917 in New York City and was survived by his wife, Fannie and his two grandchildren.<ref name="auto1"/>
